summary.p: [1] Hooper has just received a letter from John Burcher in Strasbourg. He sends greetings to [Bullinger] and his family. If [Bullinger] wishes to send something to Strasbourg, there is a presumably reliable messenger [...] who will depart tomorrow. However, he would need to deliver his dispatch to Hooper's neighbor, the carpenter [Michel] Schmid, by this evening.

[2] Burcher wrote that King Henry II of France has sent 5000 men to Scotland, along with a German Rhine Count [Johann Philipp von Salm-Dhaun-Neufville] and his mercenaries. May God grant victory to those who seek His honor the most!

[3] A large group of Spaniards, or rather a band of good-for-nothings, is encamped about 3 miles from Strasbourg during these holidays. What Emperor Charles V intends to do with them is still unknown.
[4] Hooper has a letter for John Butler, who resides in Constance. If [Bullinger] knows of a reliable messenger intending to go there, he should inform him.
[5] May the Lord Jesus always protect [Bullinger]! Greetings.

div.p: Greetings. I have just received a letter from Strasbourg from Burcher. He sends greetings to you and your entire family. If you wish to send something there, we will have a presumably reliable messenger tomorrow, as I hope, provided that your letters are delivered to our neighbor, the carpenter Michel Schmid, by this evening.

Burcher writes that King Henry II of France has sent 5000 soldiers to Scotland, and with them is a certain German count, who is called in German the Rhine Count, with his mercenaries. May the Lord grant victory to those who strive more to promote His glory!

A large group of Spaniards, or rather a band of good-for-nothings, is residing about 3 miles from Strasbourg and is taking a holiday. For what purpose Emperor Charles V will use their services is still unknown.
I have letters for John Butler, who resides in Constance. If you have someone trustworthy who is going there, please let me know, I ask.
May the Lord Jesus always protect you! Amen. Farewell. Your most devoted admirer, John Hooper.
